events.description: Antigonus I the One-Eyed executes Mithridates II of Cios, a Persian aristocrat who ruled a small city-state on the shores of the Sea of ‚Äã‚ÄãMarmara. His son, also a Mithridates, is next on the list. But Antigonus's son, Demetrius Poliorcetes, is a friend of the young man. Bound by a vow of silence, Demetrius finds a way out: while walking on the beach, he silently writes the word "RUN" in the sand with a spear.
events.name: Mithridates Escapes

events.description: The deaths of Lysimachus and Seleucus I in 281 BC created a power vacuum in Anatolia. After 20 years of guerrilla warfare, Mithridates Ktistos (the Founder) proclaimed himself King of Pontus, with his capital at Amasia, a natural fortress in a deep river gorge. His kingdom stretched along the southern coast of the Black Sea. He traced his lineage back to the Persian Achaemenid dynasty and the royal house of Kios ‚Äî half Persian, half Greek.
events.name: Foundation of the Kingdom of Pontus

events.description: Mithridates I Ktistos, the first king of Pontus, is buried in a rock-cut tomb carved into the cliff of Mount Harshena. These royal tombs‚Äîvast chambers carved from Jurassic limestone, some with Ionic columns‚Äîbecame a dynastic necropolis for five Pontic kings.
events.name: Royal Rock Tombs of Amasia

events.description: Ariobarzanes, the second king of Pontus, acquired the important Greek coastal city of Amastris in Paphlagonia‚Äîa city with two natural harbors and a thriving boxwood trade. This is the first major Greek city-state under Pontic control, giving the mountain kingdom direct access to Black Sea trade and establishing that Pontus would grow by absorbing Greek cities rather than destroying them.
events.name: Pontus Acquires Amastris

events.description: Ariobarzanes' young son, Mithridates II, inherits a vulnerable kingdom. The Galatians devastate Pontic territory. Heraclea Pontica, itself at war with the barbarians, provides military aid to Pontus.
events.name: Galatian Invasion of Pontus

events.description: Mithridates II marries Laodice, the sister of Seleucus II Callinicus and Antiochus Hierax‚Äîtwo of the most powerful men in the Seleucid empire. He receives Phrygia as his dowry. This marriage transforms Pontus from a regional outskirts into part of the Seleucid family network. It's a calculated gamble: Pontic blood is now mingled with that of Alexander's heirs.
events.name: Seleucid Marriage Alliance

events.description: Seleucus II marched into Anatolia against Antiochus' younger brother, Hierax. Mithridates II, Seleucus's son-in-law, betrayed him and allied with Hierax and the Galatians. At the Battle of Ancyra, the coalition routed Seleucus, who lost 20,000 men and barely escaped with his life. Mithridates played the great game flawlessly: he supported the victor, retained Phrygia, and established Pontus' place in Anatolian politics.
events.name: Battle of Ancyra

events.description: A catastrophic earthquake strikes the island of Rhodes, toppling the famous Colossus ‚Äî one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World ‚Äî and devastating the city's walls and dockyards. Mithridates II competes with other Hellenistic monarchs in sending magnificent gifts and aid to the Rhodians. The gesture is not merely charitable: Rhodes controls the most important trade routes in the eastern Mediterranean, and Pontic generosity buys diplomatic prestige and trading privileges that a mountain kingdom could never earn by force.
events.name: Pontus Sends Aid After the Rhodes Earthquake

events.description: Mithridates II gave his daughter Laodice III in marriage to the young Seleucid king Antiochus III. Having turned against the Seleucids a generation ago, Pontus now gave them a queen. Laodice III would become one of the most influential women in the Hellenistic world. Her Pontic blood will flow in the veins of the future Seleucid kings.
events.name: Pontic Princess Becomes Seleucid Queen

events.description: Sinop was a wealthy and independent Greek city-state with two convenient harbors, control of which would have allowed the Kingdom of Pontus to dominate the region and control the sea route to Crimea. Mithridates II suddenly declared war on the city and laid siege to it. Sinop called on Rhodes for help, and Rhodes responded with support. After several months of siege, Mithridates II was forced to retreat to avoid damaging relations with the Hellenistic world.
events.name: First Siege of Sinope by Pontus

events.description: Pharnaces I of Pontus finally conquers Sinope after several unsuccessful attempts. He made it the new capital of Pontus, leaving the former capital of Amasia as the military and logistical center. Sinope's harbors, shipyards, and control of the Black Sea trade routes transformed Pontus from a mountainous kingdom into a maritime power.
events.name: Sinope Becomes Capital of Pontus

events.description: Mithridates V Euergetes (the Benefactor) becomes king of Pontus and pursues a policy of rapprochement with Rome.
events.name: Mithridates V - King of Pontus

events.description: The rebellion of Aristonicus creates risks for other kingdoms of Asia Minor. Mithridates V personally leads the Pontic troops and navy, leading them to the Kingdom of Pergamon to aid the Roman legions. After the victory over Aristonicus, the Roman Senate, in gratitude, transferred the region of Great Phrygia to Mithridates V.
events.name: Asia Minor helps Rome in the Pergamene Revolt

events.description: Mithridates V is poisoned at a banquet in Sinope; suspicion falls on his wife Laodice VI, who immediately seizes regency over her young sons. The eldest, 12-year-old Mithridates VI, soon realized that his mother might be plotting his death. According to legend, the prince fled to the wilds of Pontus and lived as a fugitive for seven years, hunting, sleeping in the open, and hardening his body to the point of near invulnerability. During these years, he began his obsessive experiments with poisons, ingesting small doses of toxins daily to develop immunity.
events.name: Poisoning of Mithridates V ‚Äî The Boy Prince Flees

events.description: As soon as King Mithridates V died, the proconsul Manius Aquilius, who had approved the donation of Phrygia to Pontus, was accused of accepting a huge bribe from Mithridates. The Senate declared the transfer of Phrygia invalid and redefined the boundaries of the province of Asia. This became one of the reasons for Mithridates VI's hatred of Rome.
events.name: Rome takes Phrygia from Pontus

events.description: Mithridates VI returns to Sinope, deposes his mother and brother, imprisons them (they die in captivity), and then gives them a royal funeral. He marries his younger sister Laodice to preserve the family line. By all accounts, he is of enormous stature, charming, speaks 22 languages, and is an excellent horseman.
events.name: Mithridates VI Seizes Power

events.description: Mithridates marries his sister Laodice to the King of Cappadocia, Ariarathes VI. A few years later, Mithridates sent a mercenary who killed the king (his sister‚Äôs husband). Mithridates expected that now his sister would rule as regent for his young sons, obeying his brother.
events.name: Intrigues of Pontus in Cappadocia

events.description: The Pontic general Diophantus arrives with his troops to relieve Chersonesus, besieged by the Scythians under King Palakos. The Pontians defeat the Scythian army and subjugate the neighboring Taurian tribes.
events.name: Pontus protects Chersonesus

events.description: The Scythians, led by Palak, attacked again, having formed an alliance with the Roxolani under Tasius. The Pontic army defeated them and captured the capital of the Scythian kingdom, Neapolis. The Scythian kingdom in Crimea became a vassal and tributary of Pontus.
events.name: Pontus defeats the Scythians in Crimea

events.description: The Bosporan Kingdom is in deep crisis. Perisades V, the king of the Bosporan Kingdom, has no heirs and is unable to defend his lands from the raids of the Crimean Scythians. Seeing the successes of the Pontic general Diophantus in the fight against the Scythians, Perisades decided to transfer power to Mithridates VI in exchange for protection.
events.name: The Bosporan Kingdom bequeathed to Pontus

events.description: The transfer to Pontus's rule did not please the local Scythian nobility and the Scythians dependent on the Bosporus. A rebellion broke out in Panticapaeum. The rebels, led by Saumacus (who, according to one version, was Perisades's prot√©g√©, and according to another, a noble Scythian), killed Perisades V. Diophantus miraculously escaped and sailed to Pontus.
events.name: Rebellion of Saumacus in Crimea

events.description: The fading kingdom of Paphlagonia is divided between Pontus and Bithynia. Mithridates VI (Pontus) received the Black Sea coast and the eastern regions adjacent to its borders. Nicomedes III (Bithynia) received the interior and western regions. Rome objects but does not act‚Äîit is preoccupied with wars against the Numidians and Germans (Jugurtha, the Cimbri, and the Teutones). Mithridates carefully notes Rome's vulnerabilities.
events.name: Division of Paphlagonia

events.description: Mithridates could not let the death of his ally and the loss of a strategic region go unpunished. He sent Diophantus back to Crimea with a powerful fleet and land army. The rebellion was brutally suppressed, the instigators punished, and Savmak himself captured. Crimea became a province of Pontus, supplying grain, money, and soldiers for future wars with Rome.
events.name: Pontus suppresses the uprising in Crimea

events.description: Mithridates VI vassalized Colchis, the legendary land of the Golden Fleece, subjugating the entire eastern Black Sea coast. Colchis was critically important to Mithridates as a source of timber, resin, hemp, and wax for the construction of the powerful Pontic fleet.
events.name: Vassalage of Colchis

events.description: Ariarathas VII expelled his father's murderer from the country and maintained contacts with the enemies of his uncle, Mithridates. Mithridates was not pleased. Mithridates came to meet his nephew, secretly carrying a knife in the folds of his cloak, and in full view of the army, stabbed the young king to death. After this, Mithridates placed his 8-year-old son at the head of Cappadocia.
events.name: Mithridates VI kills his nephew

events.description: The Senate orders Mithridates VI to leave Cappadocia and appoints his protege, Ariobarzanes I, to the throne. Mithridates, not yet ready for a direct confrontation with Rome, concedes to the demands, but begins planning a rematch with the help of Armenia.
events.name: Rome appoints a governor in Cappadocia

events.description: Mithridates VI of Pontus marries his daughter Cleopatra to the King of Armenia Tigran II. An alliance is formed and consolidated between the Pontic and Armenian kingdoms.
events.name: The Marriage of Tigran the Great

events.description: Mithridates VI uses his family ties with the Armenian king to get rid of the Roman governor in Cappadocia without engaging in direct conflict with Rome. Tigran expels the governor, receives wealth and slaves, and transfers the lands to Pontus.
events.name: Armenia expels the Roman governor from Cappadocia

events.description: The Roman praetor Lucius Cornelius Sulla swiftly attacks and defeats the Armenian garrisons and the Cappadocian forces of Mithridates' supporters. Sulla restores Ariobarzanes to the throne and sets out to negotiate with Parthia. There, he will secure Rome's right to rule Cappadocia and deprive Mithridates of possible support from the east in the event of a war with Rome.
events.name: Sulla returns the governor to Cappadocia

events.description: Mithridates sends secret letters to governors across Asia Minor with orders: within 30 days of receipt, every Roman and Italian‚Äîmen, women, and children‚Äîis to be killed. Slaves who murder their Roman masters will be freed; debtors who murder their creditors will have their debts forgiven half. The bodies must remain unburied. Between 80,000 and 150,000 Romans were killed in Ephesus, Pergamon, Tralles, Caunus and dozens of other cities. Mithridates wants to make every Greek city complicit, making reconciliation with Rome impossible.
events.name: Massacre of Italians in Asia Minor

events.description: Rome forces Nicomedes IV of Bithynia, who is mired in debt, to invade Pontus. Mithridates, who oversees Roman politics, is prepared: Pontic armies defeat Nicomedes and sweep across Asia Minor, crushing the Romans. In a single military season, he captures Bithynia, Phrygia, Mysia, Lycia, Pamphylia, and Ionia. Greek cities open their gates voluntarily - decades of Roman extortion have made Rome hated. Mithridates is greeted as a liberator.
events.name: Mithridates Overruns Asia Minor

events.description: Mithridates dispatches the general Archelaus with a fleet and army to Greece; Several Greek states join Pontus - Athens appoints the Promitridatic tyrant Aristion. For a brief moment, it seems possible that Rome will lose the eastern Mediterranean. Mithridates skillfully exploits the civil war in Rome between Sulla and Marius to achieve his goals.
events.name: Pontic Invasion of Greece

events.description: Sulla, outnumbered by approximately 3 to 1, defeats the Pontic army‚Äîon the same field where Philip II of Macedon crushed Greek independence. Sulla's disciplined legions withstand the onslaught of Pontic chariots and phalanxes. The second decisive Roman victory follows at Orchomenus. Pontic forces are expelled from mainland Greece
events.name: Sulla Defeats Pontus at Chaeronea

events.description: Sulla and Mithridates meet at Dardanus in the Troad and conclude peace. Mithridates withdraws from all conquered territories‚ÄîAsia Minor, Bithynia, Paphlagonia, and Cappadocia‚Äîpays 2,000 talents and surrenders 70 warships. He retains Pontus and the royal title. A ruinous indemnity is imposed on the province of Asia. Both sides know this peace is temporary.
events.name: Treaty of Dardanos

events.description: Lucius Licinius Murena, whom Sulla left to govern Asia, arbitrarily crosses the border of Pontus and plunders the trading city of Comana. Mithridates, not wanting to break the peace with Sulla, does not resist and sends ambassadors with a complaint to Rome. The Senate sent an order to stop the attacks, but Murena ignored it.
events.name: Rome's invasion of Cappadocia

events.description: In a major battle near the Halys River, the Pontic army inflicts a crushing defeat on Murena's forces. The Romans are forced to retreat in disarray to Phrygia. Dictator Sulla, unwilling to become embroiled in a full-scale war in the East (as he was preoccupied with Rome's internal affairs), dispatches envoy Aulus Gabinius with orders for Murena to cease hostilities immediately.
events.name: Battle of Halys

events.description: King Nicomedes IV of Bithynia dies and bequeaths his kingdom to Rome, following the path of Pergamum. Mithridates views the Roman annexation of his neighbor as a provocation. He invades Bithynia with a massive army. This time, he forms an alliance with his son-in-law, Tigranes the Great of Armenia, creating a coalition from the Caucasus to the Euphrates.
events.name: Third Mithridatic War

events.description: Mithridates besieges Cyzicus with a massive army. The Roman general Lucullus sets up a small camp on the heights and begins attacking Pontic supply lines. Without supplies, winter, famine, and disease become critical for the army. Mithridates retreats with catastrophic losses. Lucullus pursues the retreating army, inflicting further defeats at Rhyndacus and Granicus.
events.name: Pontus sieges Cyzicus

events.description: Machar, the son of Mithridates VI, governor of the Bosporan Kingdom, after Mithridates' failures in the war with Lucullus, decided to go over to the side of Rome. Machar sent Lucullus a golden crown and requested the status of "friend and ally of the Roman people." In addition, he provided support to Lucullus during the siege of Sinope.
events.name: The Bosporan Kingdom takes the side of Rome

events.description: Lucullus invades Pontus itself and captures Sinope and Amisus, the two main Pontic cities. Mithridates flees east to the court of his son-in-law Tigranes the Great in Armenia.
events.name: Rome Captures Sinope

events.description: Lucullus demands the extradition of Mithridates; Tigranes refuses. Lucullus then invades Armenia with a small army, besieging and sacking Tigranes's magnificent new capital, Tigranocerta. Despite his numerical superiority, Tigranes fails to defeat the Romans; the Greek mercenaries of the Armenian kingdom defect to Lucullus. The new capital falls into disrepair within a few years of its foundation.
events.name: Rome ravages Armenia's new capital

events.description: While Lucullus is bogged down in Armenia with rebellious troops, Mithridates returns to Pontus with a small force and defeats the Roman army at Zela. It's a stunning turn of events‚Äîthe 68-year-old king, twice defeated and once exiled, rebuilds an army from scratch. Rome recalls Lucullus, whose brilliant strategy is undermined by the refusal of his own soldiers to fight.
events.name: Revenge of Mithridates at Zela

events.description: Lucullus was an aristocrat of the old school and forbade his soldiers from plundering provinces that had sided with Rome. He believed that Rome should bring order, not devastation. Lucullus's legions, exhausted during the campaign in Armenia, mutinied, demanding either compensation or the end of their 20 years of service in the East. The troops refused to advance further. Lucullus was pinned down.
events.name: The mutiny of Lucullus's army

events.description: Pompey the Great overtakes Mithridates at the Lycus River in Lesser Armenia. Pompey attacks at night, the moon is behind the Romans - Pontic soldiers in the darkness throw darts into the long shadows of the legionaries. The Pontic army was defeated. Mithridates flees with 800 horsemen and rides north through Colchis to the Black Sea. Pompey founded the city of Nicopolis ("City of Victory") on the site of his victory.
events.name: Battle of the Lycus River

events.description: Pompey sent an embassy to the Parthian king Phraates III and proposed an alliance with the Parthians against Tigranes II the Great, promising to recognize Parthia's disputed territories in Mesopotamia. Mithridates of Pontus would be left without a secure rearguard. Phraates III agreed and launched a large-scale offensive against Armenia, supported by the son of the Armenian king, Tigranes the Younger.
events.name: Parthian invasion of Armenia

events.description: Pompey arrives at the Roman camp in Galatia and takes over command from Lucullus. All of Lucullus's orders are revoked ‚Äì Pompey authorizes the granting of titles to local leaders in Asia Minor, abolishes tax restrictions, and allows soldiers to plunder, thereby immediately gaining the favor of various social classes.
events.name: Pompey takes command of Asia Minor

events.description: After crossing the passes, Pompey descended into Colchis and reached the city of Phasis (Poti), where the Roman fleet awaited him, blockading the coast to prevent Mithridates from returning by sea. Pompey considered that moving further through the forests of the Caucasus was risky, and Mithridates was no longer dangerous enough to pursue. Here, Pompey turned around and headed for Syria.
events.name: Pompey leaves the Caucasus

events.description: Plutarch writes that Pompey, pursuing Mithridates of Pontus, wintered in the Kura River valley. The king of Caucasian Albania, Orozos, attacked the Roman camp during the festival of Saturnalia, but Pompey unraveled the leader's plan and defeated him.
events.name: Pompey's campaign in the Caucasus

events.description: Mithridates VI succeeds in the impossible: he passes through the Caucasus to Crimea along the Black Sea coast, passing the warlike tribes of the Colchians, Circassians, and Iberians. Power in Crimea returned to Mithridates, and he began planning a new campaign to the east, planning to break through to Italy from the north with the help of the Scythians and Sarmatians.
events.name: Mithridates regains power in Crimea

events.description: Mithridates' son, Pharnaces II, wishing to break the endless cycle of war with Rome, betrays his father, rallies the garrison and the population, and besieges him in the fortress of Panticapaeum. 72-year-old Mithridates VI attempts suicide by poison, but the poison has no effect on a body hardened by decades of daily Mithridaticism. His two daughters take the same poison and die in front of him. He orders his Gallic bodyguard, Bituitus, to kill him with a sword.
events.name: Death of Mithridates the Great
